4.63.text: What is R&D in the arts?

6.97.text:
And I think all three
of us are agreeing

9.84.text:
that the answer to that question
is in the process of making.

13.52.text:
I don't think there's a
theoretical answer to it.

15.64.text:
I think there's an
emergent answer.

17.40.text:
And the emergent answer comes
from the collective practise

19.99.text:
of people doing
this sort of stuff.

23.17.text:
The R&D Fund has funded around
65 different projects, which

27.83.text:
are impressive in their variety,
as colleagues have remarked.

32.53.text:
Some will thrive, some
will not, but that's just

36.19.text:
But I just wondered, reading
through this impressive list,

39.98.text:
if you could capture any
emerging categories from them,

43.46.text:
which might define the
horizons for what R&D

47.57.text:
is in the arts in
the modern age.

50.08.text: And I came up with six.

51.27.text:
I'm sure other people can
come up with fewer or more.

54.35.text: But they struck me as these.

57.06.text:
One thread is around
increasing access,

60.04.text:
which is attending to the
particular needs of people,

63.80.text:
people who are partially sighted
or have learning disabilities

69.61.text:
So trying to customise
the experience

71.99.text:
of the arts for particular
needs is one thread.

75.30.text:
And also how to
engage people who

79.32.text:
are nonparticipants
in trying to develop

82.15.text:
their sense of
belonging to the arts.

86.59.text:
The second is a thread
around audiences,

89.05.text:
which is very prominent
in these schemes.

91.53.text:
Around audience building,
partly to do the things

94.38.text:
I've just been talking
about, but also

96.55.text:
to do with providing
information about events

100.45.text:
and improving
ticketing and so on.

103.52.text:
There's also a strand around
investigating audiences,

109.17.text:
and their behaviours and
therefore trying to be more

114.35.text:
And also, there's a great
valuing of community and place

118.42.text:
and a consciousness that
the arts only exist in

120.91.text:
so far as they have
an audience which

123.15.text:
is particular in its
needs and interests.

132.13.text:
in crowdsourcing information
around curation for museums

139.35.text:
And also in the
pro-am prosumer world

144.09.text:
where people participate
in the development of art

148.48.text: events of one kind or another.

151.56.text:
There's a thread, again,
this is the third one,

153.69.text:
around widening and enhancing
the experience of the arts,

158.00.text:
about providing supplementary
information about communicating

164.28.text:
And that is a point of
entry, I think, particularly

166.40.text:
for research, though
not exclusively so.

173.19.text:
How we can, using
digital technologies,

181.30.text:
doesn't succeed about
ticketing, marketing, promotion.

188.71.text:
That seems to me quite an
important emergent area.

196.95.text:
to break existing genres, to
look at comics, for instance,

201.63.text:
in the digital age
or graphic narratives

206.43.text:
rather than from single
points of origin.

212.81.text:
in museums or galleries
around individual preferences

221.55.text:
And then finally, new
products and new services.

224.82.text:
There's a loss of energy
around that kind of thing.

228.28.text:
Services in terms of ticketing
and marketing, as I've said

230.78.text:
earlier on, but also new
approaches to finance,

233.94.text:
about crowdsourcing finance,
about gathering together

238.54.text:
clubs for distribution and
raising funding and so on.

242.33.text:
And different ways in which
music might be conveyed.

246.15.text:
So it's a very rich,
fabulously rich group

249.55.text:
of projects, those 60 odd
of them up and down the UK.

253.57.text:
Here's, just to close,
a few reflections

256.43.text: of a general kind about these.

259.93.text:
It seems to me there are two
evolving trends in research

264.58.text:
One is that research
is collaborative,

268.48.text:
And that's one of the driving
energies of this project,

272.10.text:
But also that research
needs to increasingly occur

278.81.text:
It's something which is changing
the nature of the researcher

282.84.text:
and the object of
knowledge in ways

285.14.text:
which are subtle and
barely understood, I think,

288.09.text:
but which nonetheless are
extremely interesting.

291.74.text:
I am interested in the way
that new forms of research

294.82.text:
come and go, why they
thrive, why they emerge,

299.77.text:
And there is, I
think, at the moment

302.13.text:
an extraordinarily febrile,
full of potential moments

306.36.text:
to try and define a very
real new field in this area.

315.66.text:
There are, however, I
think, issues around this.

319.82.text:
One is the incommensurate
pace between research,

328.68.text:
They move at different time
scales, different velocities.

332.21.text:
And a lot of that
is to do is the fact

335.37.text:
different objects
at the end of it.

337.25.text:
There is a world of a
difference between a new product

339.85.text:
and an academic
article, for instance.

341.82.text:
And we need to work
harder on trying

346.45.text:
And then there are
differences, I think,

350.47.text:
Researchers tend to
belong to universities

355.58.text:
are not very
responsive in relation

357.76.text:
to the needs of SME's
and quick fire emergent

369.41.text:
They don't pay
their bills on time.

371.17.text:
They're more used to dealing
with the big corporates

373.34.text:
or they aspire to deal with
the big corporates rather

377.92.text:
And this, again, is a
long attritional thing

379.80.text:
which we're going
to have to develop.

381.34.text:
But there is a real need to
try and up the game on that.
